heading: 6.2 Oceanographic context of Perth Waters and Cockburn Sound
text: Cockburn Sound open bay situated southwestern Australian (SWA) coastal region Indian Ocean. Sound spans area approximately 80 km2 maximum depth 22m (Figure 3.1). bordered coastal line east south, Garden Island west, relatively shallow entrance north (transect Garden Island Woodman Point), depths generally less 5 meters, except narrow shipping channel 15m. geographical features give Sound ‘Mediterranean Sea’ effect, restricted flow southern entrance ocean exchange primarily occurring northern entrance. Anomalies sea level, temperature, salinity, biological activity originating broader Indian ocean can strongly influence properties SWA shelf (e.g. Gaughan Fletcher, 1997; Koslow et al., 2008; Rose et al., 2012).oceanography SWA coastal region characterized combination warm currents climate-driven changes shape marine ecosystems, affecting marine biodiversity coastal processes. region dominated Leeuwin Current, poleward-flowing, warm, nutrient-poor current. current promotes downwelling local upwelling along continental shelf, creates unique marine environment supports warm- cool-water species (Smith et al., 1991; James et al., 1999).Climatic variations, including shifts winter rainfall patterns, closely tied broader atmospheric oceanic circulation systems. Research indicates fluctuations long-term mean sea-level pressure Perth negatively correlated austral winter rainfall, trending downward recent decades, affecting freshwater input coastal dynamics (Allan & Haylock, 1993; Silberstein et al., 2012; Smith & Power, 2014). SWA coastal region also influenced strong northward winds particularly austral summer. sea breezes featured diurnal pattern, rotating anticlockwise direction translating coastal currents, particularly along shoreline within coastal embayment (Pattiaratchi et al., 1999; Gallop et al., 2012). Marine heatwaves, significant event 2011, highlight vulnerability region's ecosystems lead widespread coral bleaching, fish die-offs, harmful algal blooms (Rose et al., 2012).

heading: 7.2 Hydrodynamic setting
text: brief, purposes contextualising model approach, primary driver circulation Cockburn Sound wind, particularly prevailing south-westerly sea breeze summer months. consistent wind pattern induces two-layer circulation surface waters driven northward wind, compensatory return flow develops depth, moving southward. mechanism critical transporting heat, nutrients, properties throughout water column across basin. horizontal shear established flows generally effective promoting vertical mixing, however, periods sustained solar heating calm weather, thermal stratification intensifies, vertical mixing becomes inhibited.pattern stratification typically develops late spring can persist summer early autumn. heading: 11.1 Overview
text: Cockburn Sound undergone significant water quality changes many decades, shaped natural processes intense human activity. Understanding nutrients pollutants move system proved challenging, part Sound receives inputs many different sources. include atmospheric deposition, groundwater inflows, stormwater urban drainage, industrial wastewater discharges, well nutrients released within seabed . Although direct river flows Cockburn Sound limited, nutrient concentrations commonly rise near shoreline discharge points, occasional large flow events Swan–Canning Estuary can also influence local water quality.1950s 1980s, Cockburn Sound experienced severe eutrophication—excess nutrients fuelled high algal productivity reduced water clarity. period, wastewater industrial effluents increased substantially, construction Garden Island causeway 1970s reduced flushing nutrients open ocean. combined effect pressures dramatic: 80% seagrass meadows lost, largely due nutrient enrichment growth epiphytes blocked light reaching leaves.Significant management efforts since helped reduce nutrient loads, particularly improved wastewater treatment redirecting discharges offshore. However, legacy historical inputs remains. Nutrient-rich groundwater continues enter Sound, sandy sediments store large historical nutrient loads, internal recycling nitrogen phosphorus still contributes substantially nutrients available water column. concentrations nitrogen phosphorus declined recent decades, improvements water clarity phytoplankton biomass slower less consistent. Fish kills, algal blooms, episodes low-oxygen bottom waters continue reported. addition, hypersaline brine desalination plant shown form dense plumes may settle near seabed, reinforcing stratification making hypoxia likely certain conditions.Together, patterns highlight nutrient dynamics Cockburn Sound shaped combination external loads, internal cycling, physical processes mixing, stratification, ocean exchange. Assessing interactions requires integrated approach capable linking hydrodynamics, nutrient budgets, biological processes, local management actions. advanced biogeochemical model provides capability. allows us explore nutrients move system today, identify key environmental risks, evaluate future changes—dredging, coastal development, climate-driven shifts flows temperatures—may influence water quality.Developing model relies firm understanding broader physical environment (discussed earlier chapters) many sources nutrients entering system. Previous studies shown nitrogen, particular, plays central role controlling productivity region. Even small inputs can drive substantial ecological responses naturally low-nutrient coastal setting. Although overall nitrogen concentrations decreased due improved management, phytoplankton biomass remains elevated several locations, reinforcing need quantify external inputs internal nutrient cycling.CSIEM model domain spans wider Western Australian coastal zone therefore captures range nutrient sources beyond enter Cockburn Sound directly—including catchment discharges, groundwater inputs, wastewater treatment plant outfalls. build robust defensible modelling framework, essential clearly describe inputs shape nutrient conditions within Sound.chapter therefore outlines approach used specify external nutrient loads describes model represents internal biogeochemical cycling within Cockburn Sound. Together, components form foundation understanding present-day ecosystem conditions assessing future environmental risks.

heading: 11.2.5 Industrial inputs
text: Cockburn Sound impacted multiple industrial sources, including BP Refinery, Kwinana Power Station, Cockburn Power Station, Tiwest, Perth Seawater Desalination Plant. Despite presence industrial facilities, studies generally indicated nutrient contributions sources minimal, especially following relocation treated wastewater Sepia Depression Ocean Outlet Landline (SDOOL) 2004 (BMT, 2014 & 2018; Bekele et al., 2023). Current nutrient loads industrial sources considered negligible compared groundwater wastewater treatment plants (BMT, 2023).current study, CSIEM model configuration mirrors industrial input settings outlined BMT (2023), reflecting limited contribution sources nutrient modeling Cockburn Sound.
